case_name: Collector of Customs, Calcutta v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 21 1959 of the Special Bench of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 76 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 21 1959, of the Special Bench of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 76 of 1952. R. Prem and R. L. Dhebar, for the appellant and respondents NOS. 2 and 3.

facts.text: The respondent had imported 2000 drums of mineral oil

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had imported 2,000 drums of mineral oil. Out of this quantity, the appellant, the Collector of Customs, Calcutta, companyfiscated 50 drums by order dated September 20, 1950.

facts.text: Appellant, the Collector of Customs, Calcutta, confiscated 50 drums by order dated September 20, 1950

anchor.surface_text: Out of this quantity, the appellant, the Collector of Customs, Calcutta, companyfiscated 50 drums by order dated September 20, 1950. He also imposed a personal penalty of Rs.61,000/on the respondent under the Sea Customs Act, No. 8 of 1878,

facts.text: Collector imposed personal penalty of Rs. 61000 on the respondent under Sea Customs Act No. 8 of 1878

anchor.surface_text: He also imposed a personal penalty of Rs.61,000/on the respondent under the Sea Customs Act, No. 8 of 1878,  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The respondent appealed to the Central Board of Revenue under s. 188 of the Act,

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Central Board of Revenue under s.188 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Central Board of Revenue under s. 188 of the Act, and this appeal was dismissed in April 1952. Thereupon the respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal to Central Board of Revenue dismissed in April 1952

anchor.surface_text: and this appeal was dismissed in April 1952. Thereupon the respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court. We are in the present appeal number companycerned with the merits of the case put forward by the respondent,

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court. We are in the present appeal number companycerned with the merits of the case put forward by the respondent, for the matter has number yet been heard on the merits.

facts.text: Matter is Matter No. 76 of 1952 in Calcutta High Court

anchor.surface_text: Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 76 of 1952. R. Prem and R. L. Dhebar, for the appellant and respondents NOS. 2 and 3. P. Desai and B. P. Maheshwari, for respondent No. 1 1962. April 30.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate granted by Calcutta High Court

anchor.surface_text: WANCHOO, T.-This ii an appeal on a certificate granted by the Calcutta High Court. The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. The respondent had imported 2,000 drums of mineral oil.

facts.text: Petition came up before a learned Single Judge who referred to larger bench due to jurisdiction question

anchor.surface_text: When the petition came up before a learned Single Judge a question was raised as to the jurisdiction of the High Court to hear the petition in view of the decision of this Court in Election Commission India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao.  1  As the learned Single Judge companysidered the point important, he referred the matter to a larger bench

facts.text: Question considered by Full Bench of High Court

anchor.surface_text: and eventually the question was companysidered by a Full-Bench if the High Court. The Full-Bench addressed itself two questions in that companynection, namely,  i  whether any writ companyld issue against the Central Board of Revenue which was a party to the writ petition

facts.text: Full Bench held High Court had no jurisdiction to issue writ against Central Board of Revenue

anchor.surface_text: The Full-Bench held on the first question. that the High Court, had numberjurisdiction to issue a writ against the Central Board of Revenue in view of the Precision in the case of Sake Venkata Subba Rao. 1 . On the second question, it held that as the Central Board of Revenue had merely dis- missed the appeal

facts.text: Full Bench held High Court had jurisdiction against Collector of Customs as operative order

anchor.surface_text: On the second question, it held that as the Central Board of Revenue had merely dis- missed the appeal against the order of the Collector of Customs Calcutta, the really operative order was the order of the appellant, which was located within the jurisdiction of the High Court,

facts.text: Full Bench directed petition to be placed before Single Judge for disposal

anchor.surface_text: The Full-Bench further directed that the petition would be placed before the learned Single Judge for disposal in the light of its decision or, the question of jurisdiction. Thereupon there was an application for a certificate to appeal to this Court,

facts.text: Certificate to appeal to Supreme Court granted

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon there was an application for a certificate to appeal to this Court, which was granted and that in how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 30, 1962 by Wanchoo J.

anchor.surface_text: P. Desai and B. P. Maheshwari, for respondent No. 1 1962. April 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, T.-This ii an appeal on a certificate granted by the Calcutta High Court.

holdings.text: High Court has no jurisdiction under Article 226 to issue writ against Central Board of Revenue permanently located outside its territorial jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Full-Bench held on the first question. that the High Court, had no jurisdiction to issue a writ against the Central Board of Revenue in view of the decision in the case of Saka Venkata Subba Rao. On the second question, it held that as the Central Board of Revenue had merely dis-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent of Election Commission v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao; territorial jurisdiction limits writ issuance to authorities within High Court's local limits.

holdings.text: High Court has no jurisdiction under Article 226 to issue writ against original authority (Collector of Customs) whose order stands confirmed by appellate authority (Central Board of Revenue) located outside territorial jurisdiction upon mere dismissal of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, if the appellate authority is beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court it seems difficult to hold even in a case where the appellate authority has confirmed the order of the original authority that the High Court can issue a writ to the original authority which may even have the effect of setting aside the order of the original authority when it cannot issue a writ to the appellate authority which has confirmed the order of the original authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of merger makes appellate dismissal the operative order; writ against original would interfere with appellate order without jurisdiction over appellate; policy against indirect interference.

holdings.text: The only question for decision is whether High Court has jurisdiction to issue writ against Collector despite appeal dismissal by CBR outside jurisdiction; answer is no.

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls for decision before us is the second question debated in the High Court, namely, whether the High Court would have jurisdiction to issue a writ against the Collector of Customs Calcutta in spite of the fact that his order was taken in appeal to the Central Board of Revenue against which the High Court could no issue a writ and the appeal had been dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Framed as sole issue on certificate; resolved negatively based on merger doctrine and lack of jurisdiction over appellate.

holdings.text: Order of original authority merges in appellate authority's order even where appeal is merely dismissed without modification; appellate confirmation is fully operative order.

anchor.surface_text: The main reason which impelled the High Courts, which held otherwise, was that the order of the original authority got merged in the order of the Appellate authority when the appeal was disposed of and therefore if the High Court had no territorial jurisdiction to issue a writ against the appellate authority it could no issue a writ against the original authority, even though the appellate authority had merely dismissed the appeal without any modification of the order passed by the original authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No principled distinction between appellate reversal/modification and confirmation; all render appellate order operative; supported by Thangal Kunju, CIT v Amritlal Bhogilal, Madan Gopal Rungta; Rajasthan overruled; Mohd Nooh distinguished as pre-Constitution special case.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore feel that on principle when once an order of an original authority is taken in appeal to the appellate authority which is located beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court, it is the order after the appeal is disposed of and as the High Court cannot issue a writ against the appellate authority for want of territorial jurisdiction it would not be open to it to issue a writ to the original authority which may be within its territorial jurisdiction once the appeal is disposed of, though it may be that the appellate authority has merely confirmed the order of the original authority and dismissed the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court lacks jurisdiction to issue writ against the Collector of Customs (original authority) because the Central Board of Revenue's order dismissing the appeal is the operative order and is beyond the High Court's territorial jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: dismissed  to the Central Board of Revenue to which numberwrit, companyld be issued. The Full-Bench further directed that the petition would be placed

edges.explanation: Argument a1 that High Court had no jurisdiction against CBR outside jurisdiction supports holding h1 of no jurisdiction under Art 226 against CBR

anchor.surface_text: The Full-Bench held on the first question. that the High Court, had no jurisdiction to issue a writ against the Central Board of Revenue in view of the decision in the case of Saka Venkata Subba Rao. On the second question, it held that as the Central Board of Revenue had merely dis-

We therefore feel that on principle when once an order of an original authority is taken in appeal to the appellate authority which is located beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court, it is the order after the appeal is disposed of and as the High Court cannot issue a writ against the appellate authority for want of territorial jurisdiction it would not be open to it to issue a writ to the original authority which may be within its territorial jurisdiction once the appeal is disposed of, though it may be that the appellate authority has merely confirmed the order of the original authority and dismissed the appeal.
nd thus companyfirms the order of the original authority. It seems to us that on principle it is difficult to draw a distinction between the first tor

anchor.surface_text: We therefore feel that on principle when once an order of an original authority is taken in appeal to the appellate authority which is located beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court, it is the order after the appeal is disposed of and as the High Court cannot issue a writ against the appellate authority for want of territorial jurisdiction it would not be open to it to issue a writ to the original authority which may be within its territorial jurisdiction once the appeal is disposed of, though it may be that the appellate authority has merely confirmed the order of the original authority and dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls for decision before us is the second question debated in the High Court, namely, whether the High Court would have jurisdiction to issue a writ against the Collector of Customs Calcutta in spite of the fact that his order was taken in appeal to the Central Board of Revenue against which the High Court could no issue a writ and the appeal had been dismissed.

We therefore feel that on principle when once an order of an original authority is taken in appeal to the appellate authority which is located beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court, it is the order after the appeal is disposed of and as the High Court cannot issue a writ against the appellate authority for want of territorial jurisdiction it would not be open to it to issue a writ to the original authority which may be within its territorial jurisdiction once the appeal is disposed of, though it may be that the appellate authority has merely confirmed the order of the original authority and dismissed the appeal.
later decision of the Rajasthan High Court to which the learned Chief Justice who was party to the earlier Rajasthan case was also a party. The main r

edges.explanation: Holding resolves the issue by affirming merger even on mere dismissal

anchor.surface_text: The main reason which impelled the High Courts, which held otherwise, was that the order of the original authority got merged in the order of the Appellate authority when the appeal was disposed of and therefore if the High Court had no territorial jurisdiction to issue a writ against the appellate authority it could no issue a writ against the original authority, even though the appellate authority had merely dismissed the appeal without any modification of the order passed by the original authority.

We therefore feel that on principle when once an order of an original authority is taken in appeal to the appellate authority which is located beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the High Court, it is the order after the appeal is disposed of and as the High Court cannot issue a writ against the appellate authority for want of territorial jurisdiction it would not be open to it to issue a writ to the original authority which may be within its territorial jurisdiction once the appeal is disposed of, though it may be that the appellate authority has merely confirmed the order of the original authority and dismissed the appeal.
